title: 108_s2834
content: The Act may be cited as the "Small Business Compliance Assistance Enhancement Act of 2004". Congress finds that small businesses play a significant role in the economy, representing 99.7 percent of all employers, generating a majority of new jobs annually, and facing higher costs for regulatory compliance compared to larger firms. The Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act requires agencies to produce compliance guides for small entities, but agencies have rarely complied with this requirement and have not provided adequate assistance materials. The Fairness Act aims to clarify requirements for agencies to produce compliance guides for small businesses and ensure the provision of useful assistance materials to increase regulatory compliance. SEC. 3. ENHANCED COMPLIANCE ASSISTANCE FOR SMALL BUSINESSES. Section 212 of the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act of 1996 is amended to require agencies to publish compliance guides to assist small entities in following rules for which no certification is made by the agency head under section 605(b) of title 5, United States Code. The guides must be easily accessible on the agency's website and distributed to industry contacts. The Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act of 1996 requires agencies to publish compliance guides to assist small entities in following rules. The guides must be easily accessible on the agency's website and distributed to industry contacts. The guides should explain the actions small entities need to take to comply with a rule. The Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act of 1996 mandates agencies to provide compliance guides for small entities, detailing actions required for rule compliance. These guides may suggest procedures like tests to assist small entities without imposing additional requirements. The Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act of 1996 requires agencies to create compliance guides written in plain language for small entities to understand. Agencies can develop separate guides for different groups of small entities and collaborate with small entity associations. Additionally, a technical amendment is made to Section 211(3) of the Act.
